newsitem.title: HONG KONG: TVB banking on pick up in holiday shoppers.
newsitem.headline: TVB banking on pick up in holiday shoppers.

text.p: Hong Kong's Television Broadcasts Ltd (TVB) is hoping for a pickup in consumer spending from October to boost second-half earnings, after its interim results fell short of expectations.
"The broadcast media, like the print media, is tied to trends in advertising spending," said Alex Ying, general manager for corporate affairs at TVB.
"Our viewership increased, but the advertising market declined."
Analysts said the company's earnings performance was tied directly to trends in advertising spending which in turn are tied to consumer spending habits.

TVB surprised the market with interim results last week showing a downturn in earnings when most analysts were expecting a healthy rise. The company reported profit attributable to shareholders of HK$177.96 million, against HK$189.01 million a year earlier.
This represented a decline of 5.8 percent, while the market was expecting a rise of 20 percent.

The results of the territory's major newspaper publishing companies have been fairly dismal. Oriental Press Group Ltd , publisher of the Chinese-language Oriental Daily which has the largest circulation in Hong Kong, showed a 94 percent fall in earnings for the year to March 31, 1996.
Sing Tao Holdings Ltd, another major newspaper publisher, had a net loss of HK$146.40 million for the period.

"Compared to other media stocks, these (TVB) results were the best," said SBC Warburg Ltd media analyst Andrew Farrant. He is forecasting a double-digit percentage decline in earnings for South China Morning Post (Holdings) Ltd, whose financial year ended on June 30.
However, TVB's earnings results still have analysts baffled. While the bottom line showed a decline, turnover was HK$1.33 billion versus HK$1.195 billion, a rise of 11 percent.
Robert Fong, media analyst at HSBC James Capel Asia Ltd, said TVB's interim results showed a sharp, unexpected downturn in the company's pre-tax profitability.

"Operating profit margins fell to 15.9 percent from 19.4 percent during the first six months," Fong said. "TVB is usually fairly good at keeping costs under control, so this large shift is surprising," he said.
Analysts said this could indicate the premiums paid for prime time, which the company never clearly discloses, fell substantially.
Ying said indirect costs were kept below the level of inflation. However, he said direct costs associated with the production of more expensive programmes boosted overall costs.
In addition, TVB, which is now competing with regional broadcasters including Star TV and the territory's new cable TV service, Wharf Cable Ltd, spent more on computer facilities.
In the second half, advertising and sponsorship revenue generated from the Atlanta Olympics would give a boost to earnings, but analysts said more was required.
Consumer spending patterns in the territory follow Western holiday spending practices, with sometimes as much as 50 percent of a retailer's income derived from Christmas sales.
"If we see a drop in consumer spending during the holiday period (the fourth quarter), then we will have poorer prices (for advertising time)," Ying said.
